title: 109_s765
content: The Act may be cited as the "Math and Science Incentive Act of 2005". Congress finds the United States needs a robust scientific and technical enterprise, more scientists and engineers, improved education in science and mathematics, and a renewed commitment to research and development. The United States needs to recommit to leadership in science, mathematics, and engineering, with a focus on advancements like nanotechnology. A loan forgiveness program can attract students to careers in these fields, helping to maintain technological leadership. Establishment of program for loan forgiveness to attract students to careers in science, mathematics, and engineering fields. The Secretary will implement a program to cover interest on loans for undergraduate students who apply and meet certain criteria under the Higher Education Act of 1965. The Secretary will cover interest on loans for undergraduate students who meet specific criteria under the Higher Education Act of 1965, including teachers of STEM subjects who commit to 5 years of service. No interest payments will be made for accrued interest before the repayment period begins on certain loans. The Secretary will cover interest on loans for undergraduate students who meet specific criteria under the Higher Education Act of 1965, including teachers of STEM subjects who commit to 5 years of service. Selection for the program will be based on national security, homeland security, and economic security needs of the United States. The Secretary will consider various factors when selecting eligible applicants for the loan interest coverage program, including academic record, job performance, likelihood of completing the service obligation, staying in STEM fields, and other relevant criteria determined by the Secretary. The Secretary will prioritize interest payments based on availability of appropriations and previous fiscal year recipients. The Secretary is authorized to create regulations for this program. Interest payments will be made on behalf of student borrowers for a specified period. The Secretary will pay interest on behalf of student borrowers selected under subsection (a) for a period starting from the agreement's effective date, continuing after service completion, and ending upon loan repayment, $10,000 payment, failure to fulfill the service obligation, or 6 months after the end of a calendar year. The Secretary will pay interest on behalf of student borrowers selected under subsection (a) for a period starting from the agreement's effective date, continuing after service completion, and ending upon loan repayment, $10,000 payment, failure to fulfill the service obligation, or 6 months after the end of a calendar year. Repayment to eligible lenders will be made by the Secretary according to regulations, and an application for repayment is required. The period for interest accrual on a student loan selected under subsection (a) requires an application for repayment with specific terms. Failure to complete the service agreement results in repayment of the interest paid by the Secretary. Consolidation loans under section 428C of the Higher Education Act of 1965 are also addressed. Consolidation loans under section 428C of the Higher Education Act of 1965 may be eligible for interest repayment under specific conditions. Borrowers must meet requirements to use the loan amount for repayment of certain types of loans. Additionally, borrowers cannot receive benefits from both this section and other loan forgiveness programs for the same service. Prevention of Double Benefits: Borrowers cannot receive benefits from both this section and other loan forgiveness programs for the same service. The Act defines the terms "Secretary" and "mathematics, science, or engineering professional" and authorizes appropriations for the Act for fiscal year 2006 and the following 5 years.
